title: Safe Response Techniques
description: Learn what to do when you receive suspicious text messages and how to protect yourself from scams.

sections.title: Introduction to Safe Responses
sections.body: Knowing how to respond when you receive a suspicious text message is just as important as being able to identify it as a potential scam. This module will guide you through the appropriate actions to take when faced with suspicious messages, helping you protect your personal information and financial security.

sections.title: First Steps: Assess the Message
sections.body: When you receive a suspicious text message, your initial response is critical. Before taking any action, first assess whether the message shows common scam red flags.

interactionData.question: What should be your FIRST response when receiving a suspicious text message?

options.text: Immediately call the number provided in the message
options.feedback: This is risky! The number could connect you directly with scammers who will try to extract information or payments from you.

options.text: Reply asking for more information to determine if it's legitimate
options.feedback: Replying confirms your number is active and monitored, which can lead to more scam attempts.

options.text: Stay calm and look for red flags without engaging with the sender
options.feedback: Correct! The first step should always be to carefully evaluate the message for red flags without replying, clicking links, or calling numbers in the message.

options.text: Forward the message to all your contacts to warn them
options.feedback: While warning others about scams is good, forwarding the actual message could spread harmful links or phone numbers. It's better to describe the scam without sharing the original message.

sections.title: Don't Engage with the Sender
sections.body: The safest approach when receiving a suspicious text is to avoid engaging with the sender. Scammers want you to respond in some way—whether by replying, clicking a link, or calling a number—as this confirms your number is active and that you're receptive to their tactics.

expandableItems.title: Don't Reply to the Message
expandableItems.content: Even replying with 'STOP', 'NO', or 'REMOVE ME' confirms to scammers that your number is active and monitored. This can lead to more scam attempts and your number being added to 'confirmed active' lists that scammers sell to each other.

expandableItems.title: Don't Click on Any Links
expandableItems.content: Links in suspicious texts often lead to fake websites designed to steal your information or install malware on your device. Some sophisticated phishing sites look nearly identical to legitimate websites but have subtle differences designed to capture your login credentials.

expandableItems.title: Don't Call Provided Numbers
expandableItems.content: Phone numbers in scam texts often connect to call centers staffed by scammers who are trained to sound official and extract information or payments from you. They may use social engineering tactics to gain your trust and convince you to provide sensitive information.

expandableItems.title: Don't Download Attachments
expandableItems.content: Attachments in suspicious text messages may contain malware that can infect your device, steal your data, or even encrypt your files for ransom. Never download or open attachments from unknown or suspicious senders.

sections.title: Delete and Block
sections.body: After identifying a message as suspicious, take these immediate actions to protect yourself.

dragItems.text: Take a screenshot of the message for your records
Click the link to see where it leads
Delete the message from your phone
Forward the message to 7726 (SPAM) to report it
Call the number to tell them to stop contacting you

sections.title: Verify Through Official Channels
sections.body: If you receive a message claiming to be from a company or organization you do business with, and you're unsure if it's legitimate, verify the information through official channels rather than using the contact information provided in the message.

interactionData.question: Your bank texts you about suspicious activity on your account. What's the SAFEST way to verify if this alert is legitimate?

options.text: Reply to the text message asking for details
options.feedback: Replying to potentially fraudulent messages confirms your number is active and engaged, which can lead to more scam attempts.

options.text: Call the phone number provided in the text message
options.feedback: This is risky because scammers often include fake customer service numbers. These can connect you to people posing as bank representatives.

options.text: Click the link in the text to log in and check your account
options.feedback: Clicking links in suspicious texts is dangerous as they often lead to convincing but fake websites designed to steal your login credentials.

options.text: Call the official customer service number on the back of your bank card
options.feedback: Correct! Always contact your bank using official contact information that you've verified independently, like the number on the back of your card or from their official website that you navigate to yourself.

sections.title: Safe Verification Methods
sections.body: When verifying if a message is legitimate, always use these trusted approaches.

expandableItems.title: Use Official Contact Information
expandableItems.content: Look up the official phone number or website for the organization independently. Good sources include: the back of your credit/debit card, a recent legitimate bill or statement, the company's mobile app that you've previously installed, or a web search followed by carefully checking you're on the official website.

expandableItems.title: Log In to Your Account Directly
expandableItems.content: Open your browser or the official mobile app and manually type the website address (don't copy/paste from the message). Log in to your account directly to check for any alerts, messages, or account status. Legitimate account issues will typically be visible when you log in.

expandableItems.title: Call Official Customer Service
expandableItems.content: When calling customer service, use only numbers you've verified independently. Tell the representative about the message you received and ask them to confirm if it was legitimate. Be aware that some sophisticated scammers may try to intercept calls to legitimate numbers, so verify you're speaking with the actual company.

expandableItems.title: Visit in Person When Possible
expandableItems.content: For local organizations like your bank or credit union, an in-person visit can be the most secure way to verify suspicious communications. Bring the message with you (as a screenshot) to show a representative and confirm whether it was legitimate.

sections.title: Report the Scam Message
sections.body: Reporting scam messages helps protect others and allows authorities to track and act against scammers. There are several ways to report depending on the type of scam and your location.

expandableItems.title: Report to Your Mobile Carrier
expandableItems.content: Forward suspicious texts to 7726 (SPAM), which works with most major carriers in the US and many international carriers. This reporting method helps carriers identify and block scam numbers across their networks, reducing successful scams for everyone.

expandableItems.title: Report to the FTC
expandableItems.content: In the US, file a report at ReportFraud.ftc.gov to help law enforcement track and combat scammers. The FTC uses these reports to identify trends, build cases against scammers, and provide warnings to the public about emerging threats.

expandableItems.title: Report to the Impersonated Company
expandableItems.content: Many companies have dedicated email addresses or forms for reporting phishing attempts (e.g., phishing@bankname.com or security@companyname.com). These reports help companies take action against scammers using their brand and improve their security measures.

expandableItems.title: International Reporting Options
expandableItems.content: Outside the US, report to your country's consumer protection agency or cyber security center. For example, in the UK report to the National Cyber Security Centre at report@phishing.gov.uk, in Canada use the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre, and in Australia report to ScamWatch.

sections.title: Protect Your Personal Information
sections.body: If you suspect you may have already engaged with a scam text by sharing personal information or clicking on a link, take immediate steps to mitigate potential damage.

interactionData.question: If you accidentally clicked a link in a suspicious text message and entered your login information before realizing it might be a scam, what should you do FIRST?

options.text: Wait and see if any unauthorized activity occurs on your accounts
options.feedback: This passive approach puts you at significant risk. By the time you notice unauthorized activity, substantial damage could already be done.

options.text: Factory reset your phone to remove any potential malware
options.feedback: While this might help with malware, it doesn't address the immediate risk that your login credentials have been compromised and could be used to access your accounts.

options.text: Change your passwords immediately for the compromised account and any others that use the same password
options.feedback: Correct! Immediately changing passwords is the most critical first step to prevent unauthorized access to your accounts. Start with the compromised account, then change any others using the same or similar passwords.

options.text: Call the company that was impersonated in the scam text
options.feedback: While notifying the company is good, your immediate priority should be securing your accounts by changing passwords before scammers can use your compromised credentials.

sections.title: Recovery After Potential Compromise
sections.body: If you've accidentally engaged with a scam, follow these steps to protect yourself from further harm.

dragItems.text: Change passwords for all affected accounts
Monitor your accounts for suspicious activity
Contact credit bureaus to freeze your credit if personal info was shared
Regularly check your credit report for unauthorized accounts
Run anti-malware software on your device
Review privacy settings on all your accounts
Update your devices with the latest security patches

sections.title: Stay Informed About Current Scams
sections.body: Scammers constantly evolve their tactics, so staying informed about current scam techniques is essential for ongoing protection. Knowing about emerging threats can help you identify new scams before falling victim to them.

expandableItems.title: Follow Consumer Protection Alerts
expandableItems.content: Organizations like the FTC, FBI, CISA, and consumer protection agencies regularly publish information about new scams. Sign up for email alerts, follow their social media accounts, or check their websites regularly to stay informed about emerging threats.

expandableItems.title: Pay Attention to Company Communications
expandableItems.content: Many companies provide information about scams targeting their customers and explain how their legitimate communications will appear. Review security updates from your bank, email provider, and other sensitive services to learn what to watch for.

expandableItems.title: Use Community Resources
expandableItems.content: Forums, social media groups, and community alert systems often share information about local scam activities. Neighborhood apps, local police department alerts, and community boards can provide early warnings about scams targeting your specific area.

expandableItems.title: Follow Cybersecurity News
expandableItems.content: Reputable technology and security news websites report on significant scams and data breaches. Following these sources can alert you to major threats before they become widespread, giving you time to take preventive measures.

sections.title: Helping Vulnerable Friends and Family
sections.body: One of the most effective ways to combat scams is to share your knowledge with others, especially those who may be more vulnerable to scams due to less familiarity with technology or other factors.

interactionData.question: What's the MOST effective way to help older family members who are less tech-savvy avoid text scams?

options.text: Take control of their phone and handle all their text messages for them
options.feedback: This approach undermines independence and doesn't build skills. It's better to empower people with knowledge than to take over their communications.

options.text: Tell them to never respond to any text messages to be safe
options.feedback: This overly restrictive approach cuts people off from legitimate communications and necessary services that use text messaging.

options.text: Use real examples to teach them about red flags and create a simple verification process they can follow
options.feedback: Correct! The most effective approach is education with concrete examples and simple procedures they can follow, like 'When in doubt, don't click or reply – call me or the company directly using their official number.'

options.text: Set up text message blocking on their phone so they only receive messages from saved contacts
options.feedback: While this reduces some risk, it also blocks legitimate messages from businesses, healthcare providers, and services they use. It's better to teach recognition skills.

quiz.question: What should you do if you receive a suspicious text message claiming to be from your bank?

options.text: Reply 'STOP' to opt out of further messages
options.feedback: Replying to suspicious messages confirms your number is active and can lead to more scam attempts.

options.text: Call the phone number provided in the text message
options.feedback: Never use contact information provided in suspicious messages. Scammers often include fake phone numbers.

options.text: Find your bank's official phone number and call that instead
options.feedback: Correct! Always verify through official channels by looking up the bank's number independently and calling that number directly.

options.text: Immediately share your account details to resolve the issue
options.feedback: Never share account details in response to an unexpected message. This is likely a phishing attempt.

quiz.question: What is the best way to report a suspicious text message to help combat scams?

options.text: Forward the message to 7726 (SPAM)
options.feedback: Correct! Forwarding suspicious texts to 7726 (SPAM) helps carriers identify and block scam numbers.

options.text: Post the scammer's phone number on social media
options.feedback: This approach could violate privacy policies and doesn't help official channels track scams effectively.

options.text: Reply to the message asking them to stop contacting you
options.feedback: Engaging with scammers in any way confirms your number is active and monitored.

options.text: Do nothing, as reporting doesn't help stop scammers
options.feedback: Reporting scams is crucial as it helps authorities track patterns and take action against scammers.

quiz.question: If you accidentally clicked a link in a suspicious text message, what should you do first?

options.text: Ignore it, as no harm can come from simply clicking a link
options.feedback: Clicking links in suspicious messages can lead to malware installation or phishing sites. It shouldn't be ignored.

options.text: Change your passwords for important accounts immediately
options.feedback: Correct! If you've potentially exposed your information, changing passwords immediately is the first step to protect your accounts.

options.text: Reply to the message expressing your anger
options.feedback: Never engage with potential scammers, as this confirms your number is active.

options.text: Factory reset your phone immediately
options.feedback: While this might remove malware, it's an extreme first step. Changing passwords and monitoring accounts is the priority.

quiz.question: What is the best way to verify if a text message claiming to be from a delivery service is legitimate?

options.text: Click the tracking link in the message to check if it looks legitimate
options.feedback: Clicking links in suspicious messages is risky and could lead to phishing sites or malware.

options.text: Reply to the message asking for more details about the package
options.feedback: Engaging with potential scammers confirms your number is active and monitored.

options.text: Go directly to the delivery company's official website and enter any tracking numbers you actually have
options.feedback: Correct! Always verify through official channels by going directly to the company's website, not through links in messages.

options.text: Call the number in the message and ask if they're legitimate
options.feedback: Never use contact information provided in suspicious messages. Scammers often include fake phone numbers.

quiz.question: Why is it important to stay informed about current scam techniques?

options.text: It's not important as all scams use the same basic techniques
options.feedback: Scammers constantly evolve their tactics, so staying informed about new methods is essential.

options.text: To be able to scam the scammers back
options.feedback: Attempting to scam scammers is dangerous and could put you at greater risk.

options.text: To recognize new threats before becoming a victim
options.feedback: Correct! Staying informed helps you identify emerging scam techniques and protect yourself from new types of attacks.

options.text: Only cybersecurity professionals need to know about current scams
options.feedback: Everyone is a potential target for scammers, so everyone should stay informed about current scam techniques.

quiz.question: What's the most effective long-term protection against text message scams?

options.text: Blocking all unknown numbers on your phone
options.feedback: This approach blocks legitimate messages too and isn't sustainable as scammers constantly use new numbers.

options.text: A combination of awareness, caution, and following safe response practices
options.feedback: Correct! The most effective protection comes from building knowledge and safe habits, as no technical solution can block all scams.

options.text: Installing anti-scam apps on your phone
options.feedback: While security apps can help, they can't detect all scams and create a false sense of security. Education and caution are still essential.

options.text: Changing your phone number frequently
options.feedback: This disruptive approach doesn't provide lasting protection, as scammers target ranges of numbers rather than specific individuals.
